topics.name: Combined Rich Text Example
topics.definition: # ICT Tutorial: Data Structures A **data structure** is a specialized format for {color:#FF5722}organizing{/color} and {color:#2196F3}storing data{/color}. ## Types of Data Structures: • Linear: Arrays, Linked Lists, Stacks, Queues • Non-linear: Trees, Graphs, Hash Tables ## Array Example: ```kotlin val numbers = arrayOf(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) val sum = numbers.sum() println("Sum: $sum") // Output: 15 ``` ## Time Complexity: The time complexity for searching in an array is $O(n)$ where $n$ is the size. Binary search complexity: $$T(n) = O(\log n)$$ {size:20}Key Points:{/size} 1. Choose the right data structure for your problem 2. Consider time and space complexity 3. Understand trade-offs between different structures

topics.name: Network Topology
topics.definition: # Network Topology Network topology refers to the arrangement of elements (links, nodes, etc.) in a {color:#673AB7}computer network{/color}. ## Common Types: ### 1. Star Topology • All devices connect to a central hub • Easy to add new devices • If hub fails, entire network fails ### 2. Bus Topology • All devices connected to a single cable • Cost-effective for small networks • Performance degrades with more devices ### 3. Ring Topology • Each device connects to exactly two others • Data travels in one direction • Failure of one device affects the whole network ## Network Speed Formula: Bandwidth calculation: $$B = \frac{D}{T}$$ Where: - $B$ = Bandwidth - $D$ = Data transferred - $T$ = Time taken ## Implementation Example: ```kotlin data class NetworkNode(val id: Int, val name: String) class Network { private val nodes = mutableListOf() fun addNode(node: NetworkNode) { nodes.add(node) println("Added: ${node.name}") } } ``` ![Network Diagram](https://github.com/shibbir001/myImageofproject/blob/main/board_question/2025/dha23Cha32.PNG?raw=true)
allExamples: Star: Central hub controls all communication
Mesh: Every device connected to every other
Hybrid: Combination of two or more topologies
